text: putting it in here for visibility

Hi!

We have been running <http://arabdocphotography.org|arabdocphotography.org> on hostmonster for over a year with very few issues. Earlier this week, we found the site to be down – logging in via ssh and restarting the mongo daemon, it appeared to work again, only to go down after 10 minutes.

Per <https://my.hostmonster.com/cgi/help/478>, it appeared to be because we were on a Shared IP, though we had not had issues before. Since we are on a business pro account, we migrated to our included dedicated IP in hopes to resolve the issue.

After migration, it appears that any processes started during the session are terminated when the session ends. Though it should not be necessary with a daemon such as mongod, tech support offered the following solutions: <http://www.tecmint.com/keep-remote-ssh-sessions-running-after-disconnection/>

Unfortunately, screen does not work with the configured shell (Cannot access ‘/dev/pts/1’: No such file or directory), tmux is not installed, etc. Even using nohup, the process is killed, as viewed from the cpanel process manager.

As our configuration worked for over a year, I was concerned that this might be an issue with jailshell destroying its environment. The cpanel interface lets me change the shell to bash from the dropdown, but it unfortunately only sets it to jailshell.

The command we’re using to invoke mongo is

mongod --fork --dbpath /home2/arabdocp/mongodb/data --smallfiles --logpath /home2/arabdocp/mongodb/data/mongodb.log

where --fork forks the process to run in the background as a daemon. It should not be tied to the user session.

We’d very much like to get the site back up and running, and to do so will need to get mongod to run in the background, as it has on our hostmonster instance for months. Can you advise why all background processes appear to be getting killed on session logout?

Thanks,
Charles

attachments.title: Process / Script Times Out After 10 Minutes
attachments.text: My process for my script / program is timing out after 10 minutes. Domain registration, domain hosting, domain renewals, domain transfers and much more - FASTDOMAIN
attachments.fallback: Process / Script Times Out After 10 Minutes

attachments.title: 5 Ways to Keep Remote SSH Sessions and Processes Running After Disconnection
attachments.text: In this article, we will explain five useful techniques to keep your remote SSH terminal sessions running even after session disconnection under Linux systems.
attachments.fallback: 5 Ways to Keep Remote SSH Sessions and Processes Running After Disconnection
